bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 169, Number 68 (Monday, April 24, 2023)][House]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. CORREA:H.R. 2802.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article 1 Section 8The single subject of this legislation is:This bill requires institutions of higher education (IHEs)that participate in federal student-aid programs to sharecontact information for suicide prevention resources withstudents[Page H1915]

item.title: Improving Mental Health Access for Students Act

latestAction.text: Read twice and referred to the Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions.

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on Education and the Workforce.

summary.text:
Improving Mental Health Access for Students Act

This bill requires institutions of higher education (IHEs) that participate in federal student-aid programs to share contact information for suicide prevention resources with students.

If IHEs distribute student identification cards, then they must include on the cards phone numbers for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline, the Crisis Text Line, and a campus mental-health center or program.

If IHEs do not create such cards, then they must publish the numbers on their websites.

bill.title: Improving Mental Health Access for Students Act

item.title: Improving Mental Health Access for Students Act
Improving Mental Health Access for Students Act
To add suicide prevention resources to school identification cards.

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Education and the Workforce.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
